awd_abstract_narration: This proposed task provides the support for a community meeting by the Federal agencies, whose mission is to advance the science and technology of cyber security, with leading experts and researchers in academia, industry, and government at the Gaylord National Hotel and Convention Center, National Harbor, Maryland. This meeting will focus on recent progress in developing the scientific foundation for the design and analysis of trusted systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The National Security Agency (NSA) sponsored the first official Science of Security Community Meeting on November 29-30, 2012 in the Washington. DC area where a diversity of over 150 leaders from government, industry, and the academic national and international communities met to discuss new and ongoing programs in security science that would provide first principles and the fundamental building blocks for security trustworthiness being pursued by U.S. government research sponsor agencies as well as a new Cyber Security Research Institute recently launched in the United Kingdom. Numerous groundbreaking presentations were introduced representing a broad range of disciplines, including, mathematics, computer science, behavioral science, economics, physics, and biology. The meeting spawned the following outcomes:

  1. Science of Security lablet research centers selected to focus on the development of an SoS and broad, self-sustaining community effort to advance SoS research. The lablets proposed a “Hard Problems Structure” that can be used to organize their content and potentially future research.
  2. The officially launched Science of Security Virtual Organization (SoS VO) as well as the Science of Security Community Meeting Website that can be found at http://cps-vo.org/group/SoS and http://cps-vo.org/group/sosmtg, respectively. The SoS VO was broadly established to accelerate the national research agenda and showcase results of the NSA-led new Science of Security research initiative, and to aid in the development of a virtual SoS research collaboration community. All artifacts, including presentations, posters, abstracts, videos, and data bases of the meeting have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public website developed for the 2013
  3. The first NSA Competition for the Best Scientific Cybersecurity Paper designed to encourage the development of scientific foundations of cybersecurity and showing outstanding contributions to cybersecurity science. Awardees were invited to NSA to receive the award and the top awardee was invited to present the winning paper to an audience of cybersecurity experts and government personnel.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2013
Modified by: Christopher P Buskirk

The National Security Agency (NSA) sponsored the first official Science of Security Community Meeting on November 29-30, 2012 in the Washington. DC area where a diversity of over 150 leaders from government, industry, and the academic national and international communities met to discuss new and ongoing programs in security science that would provide first principles and the fundamental building blocks for security trustworthiness being pursued by U.S. government research sponsor agencies as well as a new Cyber Security Research Institute recently launched in the United Kingdom. Numerous groundbreaking presentations were introduced representing a broad range of disciplines, including, mathematics, computer science, behavioral science, economics, physics, and biology. The meeting spawned the following outcomes:

Science of Security lablet research centers selected to focus on the development of an SoS and broad, self-sustaining community effort to advance SoS research. The lablets proposed a "Hard Problems Structure" that can be used to organize their content and potentially future research.
The officially launched Science of Security Virtual Organization (SoS VO) as well as the Science of Security Community Meeting Website that can be found at http://cps-vo.org/group/SoS and http://cps-vo.org/group/sosmtg, respectively. The SoS VO was broadly established to accelerate the national research agenda and showcase results of the NSA-led new Science of Security research initiative, and to aid in the development of a virtual SoS research collaboration community. All artifacts, including presentations, posters, abstracts, videos, and data bases of the meeting have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public website developed for the 2013
The first NSA Competition for the Best Scientific Cybersecurity Paper designed to encourage the development of scientific foundations of cybersecurity and showing outstanding contributions to cybersecurity science. Awardees were invited to NSA to receive the award and the top awardee was invited to present the winning paper to an audience of cybersecurity experts and government personnel.
